description: A roll-and-move game along a 100-space track depicting the various expeditions that discovered and settled Australia, from De Quiros and Torres in 1605, Tasman (1642), Dirk Hartog (1616), Dampier (1688 & 1699), Cook (1770), Phillp (1788), Bass (1798), Grant (1800) and Flinders 1802-03. Brief historical notes are given, and various spaces give penalties and bonuses.

Iron Magicians is an interactive, pick-your-panel graphic novel for middle grade readers, full of adventure, magic, and fun!

In a steampunk version of nineteenth-century Paris, magical mana crystals have replaced steam and coal to power the machines and gadgets that make the city tick. On the eve of the Universal Exhibition of 1889, France seeks to demonstrate its power by unveiling a new secret weapon: the imposing Eiffel Tower, built with magic by Gustave Eiffel himself. But then disaster strikes--the mana crystals needed to power the tower are discovered missing!

You are a talented student in technomagy, the artful blend of magic and science. You are tasked with the mission of finding enough mana crystals to operate the tower. It's up to you to harness your intelligence, bravery, and skill to fulfill this secret mission.

—description from the publisher

Control monsters to steal candies!

In Kingdom's Candy: Monsters, you are a villain eager to accumulate candies. You use monsters as servants to help you in your mission, but if you don't feed your monsters, they will eat your candies and run away! Use sugar cubes to cast spells and activate monster abilities.

—description from the designer

Birdtrails is a pair of educational race games featuring 140 different kinds of North American birds.

In Game 1, placers roll and spin to make it back to the trailhead with the most impressive collection of birds seen.  Special points are awarded for taking time to improve the birds' habitat!

In Game 2, players do not use the spinner, and can only collect birds if they are able to correctly identify them, based on a photo.  Random events are reduced, making it more a game of skill and knowledge.

The game comes with 300 beautiful cards, featuring nature photography by Bob Ball.  A handful of scoring variants are also included.

Endorsed by the Greater Ozarks Audubon Society.

This early product of Zoo-phonics uses different decks with sets of pairs of cards. One deck has 26 pairs for each letter of the alphabet, along with the name of the animal assigned to that letter, e.g. Allie Alligator, Honey Horse, Vincent Vampire Bat. Another deck has 40 pairs of 2- or 3-letter blends and digraphs.

The three games are adaptations of traditional childrens' games: Zoophonia (Old Maid, except the one with the Zoophonia card wins); Zoo-Fish (Go Fish), and Zoo-Memory (Memory).  The alphabet deck also says it can be used for spelling games.  Whenever cards are requested or matches made, the player must say the card's animal name, make its sound, and do its sign according to the Zoo-phonics kinesthetic system.

—user summary

There are only two time-travel devices in existence, and you and your friend have managed to steal them. They will allow you to be the perfect thieves, traveling through time to when your target is most vulnerable and snatching it away to the future ... er, present.

It wouldn't have been possible without your friend, but now that you have the time-travel device, you don't need him. So you have decided to go back to the night the time-travel devices were invented and steal them BOTH. Unfortunately, your backstabbing buddy had the same idea.

GOAL

You need to infiltrate the facility with the time-travel devices while the cameras are off, the alarm is disabled, and the robot guard is deactivated. If neither player successfully infiltrates, or both players infiltrate at the same time, shuffle the decks and start a new game. After all, you can both travel through time, so you might as well try again.

—description from the box and the rulebook

"A unique card game of Spelling and Poker."

The Deck: The cards have traditional playing cards suit and rank in one corner (e.g. two of clubs, queen of hearts), and a letter of the alphabet in the opposite corner.  There are also 2 jokers.

Play: For a hand, each player is dealt 7 cards, and looks for both the best poker hand, and the longest word, they have in their hand. Then each player holds out a fist with 0-2 tokens in it, and all open their hands at the same time.  0 tokens means they are trying for the best poker hand, 1 token for the longest word, 2 tokens for both (Double Down).

Scoring: For those trying for just the best poker hand, or just the longest word, the player who has the best hand gets 1 point, with tied players each getting 1 point.  A player going Double Down must have the best hand in both areas, with no ties. If they do, they get 4 points, if not, they lose 2 points.

More hands are played until one player has 12 points in a 2-player game, 10 points for 3 or 4, 8 points for 5 or 6, 6 points for 7 or 8.

—user summary

Adrift: Lost at Sea is a 2 - 4 player co-operative ocean survival game. The players, the stranded crew in a life raft, work together to survive until the event deck runs out. Each event brings challenges such as storms, rotting food, or heat stroke.

Each turn, players choose actions such as fishing, repairing the boat, navigating, nursing each other back to health, or curing ailments. Each action has a cost in fish, and must also be balanced with other players' actions or cause additional structural damage to the flimsy vessel. Meanwhile, precious drinking water is constantly running out, and can only be replenished through a fortunate turn in the weather.

If your crew survives the harrowing journey, you can sing a sea shanty of your exploits, by compiling the verses written on the bottom of each event card.

Description from the publisher:

Adrift: Lost at Sea is a challenging, 2 - 4 player, cooperative card game that focuses on bringing people together. It’s like the Oregon Trail meets a 16th Century shipwreck - As you make the journey back home on the unforgiving tides, your table becomes the lifeboat and you become the survivors. Plus, at the end of the game, you'll get a unique sea shanty about your voyage to sing (or chant) together and reminisce about your adventure!

On this journey home, you'll endure storms, navigate the seas, balance and repair your tiny lifeboat, fish for sustenance, and work together to help each other survive!

Players try to complete all cards in the route home deck while outlasting storms and maladies to win the game.

Voyage boldly into the strange new worlds of Star Trek and the incredible adventures of the U.S.S. Enterprise by pitting your wits against this collection of puzzles inspired by the brilliant and ever-logical Mr. Spock.

'Star Trek: Spock's Logic Puzzle Box can be played alone, with friends or as a team competition. Two to six players work best.

—description from the publisher

NAPOLEON RETURNS 1815 is our first game using our action point/battle card system.  We've combined several ideas into one fast playing game of Napoleon's 1815 Waterloo Campaign.

With fewer than 20 pieces on the board, strategic movement based on action point allocation, a unique twist on a classic battle card system, the game plays in under 90 minutes.  The game is playable by 2 to 3 players and several games can be played in an evening.  Great for Tournament play!
 Each side receives a set number of action points to move pieces and battle.  Each piece on the board is a corps in the French, Anglo-Allied, and Prussian armies, so each side has 4 - 8 pieces on board.  As your pieces move they will gain fatigue, and as they battle they gain fatigue and casualties.

The battle system is card play, matching the cards played based on the type of units in the corps (infantry, cavalry, or artillery).  Victory is determined by the capture of terrain and eliminating enemy units.

-description from publisher

The set contains
- 2 sets of rules
- 2 sets of player aid card
- Mapboard
- 2 French army tracking card sheets
- 1 Allied army tracking card sheets
- 1 Prussian army tracking card sheets
- 5 objective cards
- 68 combat cards
- 8 French unit blocks
- 10 Allied & Prussian unit blocks
- 25 yellow multipurpose market blocks
- 1 six sided die

This game dates back to the Persians, who played a crude version in which the board was thirteen feet across. The counter was made of stone and took forty slaves to lift; as a result, play was slow. Modern gamers have speeded play, but have not modified the basic futility of the system.

First published in The Space Gamer (Issue 62 - Apr 1983), under Famous Game Designers' School.

Hemlock is a strategic, medieval themed, card game.

In it, your goal is to manipulate an unfolding conspiracy to your advantage. Populate your King's court with high-valued figures, reduce the likelihood of their deaths, and minimize your opponents’ ability to do the same.

Hemlock features a play deck of 66 cards (11 cards per suit). Each card has a static or variable point value as well as an associated ability. When a player plays a card from their hand, they choose to play it for either points or for ability.

Hemlock is played over a series of rounds. At the beginning of each round, 2 cards are dealt face down to the center of the play area. These are the conspiracy cards. Actions played during the course of a round can change the conspiracy cards, but there are always, and only, 2 conspiracy cards in a given round.

Players take turns moving clockwise, playing 1 card per turn from their hand with the goal of accruing the highest round-point total. The player with most points at the end of a round earns the privilege of examining the 2 conspiracy cards and then assigning them to 2 different players' courts (score piles).

The number of cards in each player's court is known to all, but the value of the cards are kept secret even to their owner until a specified number of cards is present in a given court. When this number of cards is reached, the game ends. Players tally the value of the cards in their court (the ones that aren't poisoned by Hemlock!) and the player with the highest valued court wins.

—description from the publisher

Something's rotten in the realm of Labamba...

The annual rave party is an event where every self-respecting wizard and sorceress has to make an appearance; however, this year's party was so epic, that in the morning the guests – all tired and hungover – discovered that someone has murdered the Archmage!
No one knows how, no one knows when. It's quite possible that even the murderer him or herself is not aware of what happened last night, since barely anyone remembers anything. Unfortunately, according to the ancient laws of Labamba, the one that kills the Archmage may become a powerful Darchmage, bringing Darkness onto the land. And if there is one thing that Darkness hates, it's fun, techno, lasers and glitter – which is all that is dear to the magical folk.
Thus, it's time to pull yourselves together, put your holo detective hats on your aching heads and catch the killer, before he grows too powerful!

RAVEHARD: Magiczna Gra Karciana is a party game that mixes elements of classic card battle games, games of deduction and deception, as well as more cooperative titles. It's meant to be played by 2-5 players aged 12 and more.

Over the course of the game, which lasts three rounds, the players will have to work together in order to discover who killed the Archmage during the magical rave party yesternight. To achieve this goal, they'll have to overcome dangerous obstacles, including boss fights (each boss capable of summoning powerful minions) and unpredictable events. After each round the players gain a new clue which sheds some light on the last night's incident and points towards a possible murder weapon.
If the players manage to survive all three rounds, they reach the Archmage's Chamber. There they may incapacitate one of them, should they be certain that he's the killer. If they are correct – they win the game; if they are wrong – the murderer steps out of the shadows and attacks the rest of the players. The side that emerges victorious from this final confrontation wins the game.

Do not trust anyone – not even yourself! Each player starts the game with two different objects which may turn out to be the murder weapons – or they may prove your innocence. During your turn you may switch the objects with those belonging to other players in order to frame them and clear your name. However, not until the very end will it be possible to tell which object is really the murder weapon. Thus, during the game you'll have to bluff, form alliances, deceive and distract, both openly – and secretly, using the Flirt Cards that let you pass private messages, scheme and conspire (and flirt).

This game is for you if you enjoy playing such titles as Magic: The Gathering, Munchkin, Hero Realms, Epic Spell Wars of the Battle Wizards, Love Letter, Mascarade, Coup, Not Alone, PENNY DREADFUN: Duchy, Demony, Dickensy.

—description from the publisher

Ravehard: Magiczna Gra Karciana to gra dla 3-5 graczy w wieku 12+ Å‚Ä…czÄ…ca elementy klasycznej gry karcianej, gry blefu i dedukcji oraz gry kooperacyjnej.

JeÅ¼eli nie – morderca ujawni siÄ™ i zapoluje na graczy: druÅ¼yna, która wygra ostateczne starcie, wygrywa grÄ™.

Nie ufaj nikomu, nawet sobie! KaÅ¼dy z graczy rozpoczyna grÄ™ z pewnymi przedmiotami, które Å›wiadczyÄ‡ mogÄ… o ich winie lub stanowiÄ‡ alibi. W czasie swojej tury gracze mogÄ… podrzucaÄ‡ innym te przedmioty, próbujÄ…c zwaliÄ‡ winÄ™ na nich i oczyÅ›ciÄ‡ siÄ™ z zarzutów. Jednak do samego koÅ„ca nie bÄ™dzie wiadomo, który przedmiot naprawdÄ™ okaÅ¼e siÄ™ narzÄ™dziem zbrodni. Przez caÅ‚Ä… rozgrywkÄ™ gracze bÄ™dÄ… blefowaÄ‡, zwieraÄ‡ sojusze, oszukiwaÄ‡
siÄ™ nawzajem i mÄ…ciÄ‡ – jawnie oraz niejawnie – przy wykorzystaniu specjalnych kart Flirtu, sÅ‚uÅ¼Ä…cych do przekazywania sobie informacji i knucia.

—description from the publisher (Polish)

Monaco has two identical decks of 54 cards. 52 of them have:

     Traditional playing card ranks and suits in the upper left corner (e.g. King of Spades)
     A one- or two-letter prefix in the upper left corner (copied in small print above the card's rank). 
     Four suffixes of 1-4 letters listed below the card's suit along the left side. Each suffix is printed in either black, red, green or brown ink; the mix and order of the colors varies from card to card, so the color is probably significant but the pattern is hard to discern. 


The remaining 2 cards contain a list of 300 words, each of which is a combination of a prefix and a suffix from the other cards. These words actually look mostly like nonsense words and are likely a set of names, perhaps associated with Monaco.

It looks apparent that an important part of the game is to combine cards so that a prefix and a suffix combine to make a word in the list.  But the game's mechanics, the meaning of the different colors, and even its publication details are unknown until a copy of their rules can be found.

—user summary

Object of the game is to remove all the bolts from Frankenstein's foot one by one using the included "mad scientist wrench" tool. One wrong move and the foot comes "alive". There are several difficulty levels the game can be set to. The players are eliminated if they cause the foot to move - the last player standing is the winner.

—user summary

Race to Planet X: Number Bond Game is a board game that has fun game mechanics and helps K-3rd graders master number bonds, addition, and subtraction. Families can play a quick game in 15 minutes, and score some major parenting points for non-screen family time that also doubles as math practice for the kids.

The Game: 

     Take turns making Power Combos (3 cards that make a number bond) to move forward on the game board. 
     Make Power Combos before another player ZAPs a card from your hand. SCORE your Power Combos before another player SMASH one and make you move backwards. 
     First to reach Planet X wins!


—description from the publisher

In X Arrr!, 2-4 pirate crews journey around an island full of secret paths to collect their buried treasure. X marks the spot! The first player to get both pirates and all of their treasure back to their ship is the winner. Arrr!

The island is built randomly from discs showing paths that can be rotated to link with the paths on neighbouring island discs. On their turn players can change paths or rotate any island disc. Pirates automatically move forward if rotating an island disc extends the path the pirate is on, and if they pass over a treasure they’ll pick it up, but end their turn on the same disc as another pirate crew and they’ll be ambushed.

It takes skill to navigate the island, collect all the treasures, and avoid the other pirate crews, but make the right moves and a pirate can travel long distances along the same style of path in their turn.

X Arrr! usually plays in 20-25 minutes. It has simple rules and simple actions but still requires players to think and plan to win the game.

—description from the designer

Wobuga comes from WOrd BUilding GAme.

It includes 72 letters: 6 each for A, E, I, O; 4 each for U, Y; 2 each of all other letters.

To start, the letters are stirred face down, and each player draws 5 letters. A turn consists of drawing a letter and then either making a word out of one's hand, or adding one or more letters to words already on the table without rearranging their order.  After playing, a player draws again and continues playing until announcing "I am thru", and the turn goes to the left. One can also make a sentence out of their own words, after which those words cannot be further altered. When a turn is over and other players see plays they could have done, they say "Wobuga" and can make the play for them and score the points they could have scored.

Points scored are: 5 points for each letter played during one's turn, 10 points for each word of a sentence, and 25 points for making the word "Wobuga".  The highest score when all the letters are used wins.

There is also a solitaire mode where a player takes repeated turns and tries to use all the letters.  Also, Wobuga Rush, where two players each play with a half deck in solitaire mode, and play through all their letters.  Each player gets 5 points for each letter not used, and -10 points for being the first to say "I am thru"; the lower score wins.

—user summary

Skruuvi is a Finnish relative of Auction Whist (which is essentially Bridge without a dummy).

Like Bridge, it's a four player, partnership trick taking game. Players bid how many of the thirteen tricks their partnership can win (or, unlike Bridge, lose). Also, players can communication information about their hands through their bids (and, unlike Bridge, the cards they can exchange) with a system of conventions. Here are the main differences:


     Players get to exchange cards with each other. There are two ways of playing Skruuvi depending on how players exchange cards: Kitty games and No-kitty games.


- In a Kitty game, players receive 12 cards; the four undealt cards is the kitty. The highest bidder adds the kitty to their hand, then gives any four cards to their partner. The partner adds these cards to their hand, then gives one card to each of the other three players.

- In a No-kitty game, players receive 13 cards. The highest bidder gives any four cards to their partner. The partner adds these cards to their hand, then returns any four cards back to the highest bidder.


     Players optionally play several rounds of Bolshevik, where one player attempts to win or lose all 13 tricks (without a partner).



     Players can bid misere, which is a bid of how many tricks a partnership will lose (without a trump suit).



     As mentioned, there is no dummy!



     As in Bridge, the lowest bid is to win 7 out of the 13 tricks. However, the lowest bid you can win the auction round is 11 tricks! (Or for misere bids, to lose 11 tricks!) In No-kitty games, the lowest bid is to win 12 out of the 13 tricks. 



     A game of Skruuvi lasts 24 rounds. Each player plays with a different partner for 8 rounds each.


—user summary

It's time for two teams to go head-to-head in a fast and furious game of ridiculous challenges. Jump into the hot seat, flip the timer, and get going!

Choose a player to referee the contest in 20 Second Showdown. Everyone else splits into two teams and sits opposite each other, face-off style. At the beginning of each round, the referee resets the timer with an even amount of "sand" in each half. The referee's job is to read out the challenges and flip the timer, which has twenty seconds of sand in each half. To win, you need to force the other team to run out of "sand" by completing your challenges as quickly as possible. The first team to run out of "sand" loses the round, and the first team to win three rounds is crowned "20-Second Champions".

—description from the publisher

Mindblock plays similar to Rummikub in that players have a hand of items and want to play them into a common space in sets and runs, with those sets and runs being breakable should you be able to rearrange things in order to play more from your hand.

What's different about Mindblock is that players can stack smaller blocks together in order to use them as a larger number, giving you more play opportunities to get pieces out of your hand.

About: In Cyber Siege everyone is a hacker trying to gain control of the system through use of programs, once you have uploaded or install all your bytes of data to the system you have taken control. Cyber Siege is a game that uses temporary alliances, strategy, and program actions to advance your own agenda, or slow down your opponents. Discussion, deals, persuasion, and even temporary treaties are allowed and encouraged. Turns are fast in this game and everyone stays engages the whole game. The rules are simple to understand but there is still strategic depth. Players will attempt to take control of Programs by installing more bytes of data then their opponents.

Victory Condition: Be the first player to Upload or Install all your bytes of data from your hard drive into the System!

Game Play: 
Cyber Siege consists of several game rounds separated into three phases:

     Install Phase: Players take turns installing bytes of data into one of many programs in order to take majority control and take the programs action.
     Execution Phase: Players take turns executing programs. Each program has a special ability that either helps yourself or hurts one of your opponents. But because the scoring is hidden no one knows for sure who is winning, therefor deflection and collusion to change who to attack is an open table discussion.
     Packet Generation Phase: Players simultaneously generate there data packet (the number of bytes of data they will get to install on the following round) based upon the actions executed by the program.


—description from the publisher

Game of battles with miniatures. Quick and easy rules to play immediately. The game comes with a book with the basic rules and lists of fighters. It is proposed as a cooperative game, in which different players (or only one) face an automated and undaunted enemy that does not know surrender.

—description from the designer

A simple tile placement game; 27 planet tiles are piled in a random heap on the table and players take turns selecting one that has no other tile on top of it and placing it in their "galaxy."

Planet tiles each have three characteristics: size, color, and type. Once the tiles are taken as evenly as possible players score for lines of three planets which share a characteristic.

—user summary

The grape pickers are fighting to inherit a magnificent but nearly abandoned vineyard. Whoever is able to harvest the best grape yield from the vines will become the owner of this precious land.

In La Viña, the players advance along the board, collecting cards with the most interesting grapes. To collect the cards you advance along a track that represents the rows of a vineyard. Each track has a series of different grape cards on either side, and you are allowed to choose the cards next to the space you are on, or next to the space you move to. Each turn you can choose a card and advance or advance and choose a card.

At the end of the track, there are different wineries (each preferring a different kind of grape variety). Get the best reward for your harvest from the local wineries by matching your hand of grapes with their needs. If the players go quickly, they may get the best cards, but risk not having enough grapes. If they go too slow, the competition can beat them to the best vines!

Selling your grapes to the wineries gets the players prestige points, and each player has a limited amount of deliveries. The end game triggers when a player makes their last grape delivery. The other players can finish moving through their track. Then, everyone counts their prestige points gained through their previous deliveries, and the player with the most points wins!

—description from the publisher

The pantry shelves are nearly overflowing with food and the mice are rushing to collect what they need to ensure their families have enough to eat through the harsh winter. Each family forages for themselves, trying to do the best for the wee offspring. The first to fill their little sack will be the envy of all mousedom.

Ratzzia is a game for two to five players. The dice represent the mice in each player’s family. Each time they roll the dice they must arrange the die results on the board in order to get as much food as possible.

Each player has their own set of colored dice. On their turn, they roll their dice and choose to place them on the matching spaces on the board. The dice represent mice climbing on top of each other in order to get rewards from the top shelf.

Rewards can be delicious food, or actions that help you store or steal food. After collecting some food, it needs to be stored, otherwise it can be stolen by other players! As soon as a player gets 25 points worth of food, they win the game and survive the winter!

—description from the publisher

For the 20th anniversary of Roads & Boats, the game is being reprinted for the fifth time. This edition will include the &Cetera expansion, so the game can be played with up to six players and you will get all the additional modules of &Cetera included in the game. There are no other changes to the game.

In Roads & Boats, each player builds a civilization over a long period of time, as in many other games. Unlike most games, however, the emphasis is not on warfare, population growth, city or statebuilding, but on logistics, or rather on transport. Each player starts the game with three donkeys, a pile of wooden boards, a number of stones, and two geese. With these few resources, you try to build such diverse things as woodcutters, roads, boats, mines, a stock exchange... but beware! There is no concept of territory in this game! You cannot own land, nor buildings, so the things you build can be used by any other player...

The original game can be played by two to four players, but it can also be used as a one-person puzzle.

&Cetera adds new buildings, new goods, new land types, new transporters, new ways to win, and new strategies. It also includes 24 new scenarios and material to play with five or six players. & Cetera contains all the rules and material previously published as Planes & Trains, plus a lot more.

—description from the publisher

Brexit: The Real Deal is a card game in which 3-5 players compete to win trade deals with other countries. You'll have to plan, bluff and second guess what everyone is doing as you try and complete your hidden agenda and stop them completing theirs!

Unlike the classic card game, Mau Mau - the board game is not just about getting rid of your cards quickly and saying Mau Mau - it's about get as many points as possible. Shouting Mau Mau doesn't end the game, but gives you 5 bonus points. Playing identical cards and some special spaces also wins bonus points. The game ends when all the spaces on the board are covered with cards. The winner of this fast-paced board game version of the classic card game is the player who scored the most points!

—description from the back of the box

Draw two on the 7, skip a turn on the 8 - the famous card game mau mau gets its own special charm as a board game. Anyway, if Reiner Knizia takes over the implementation.

Placing a suitable card on another, the next player must react - this is the classic principle of mau mau. The suit or number must match the previously placed card. Reiner Knizia has transferred this principle to the game board: tiles are placed on a path. The color or symbol shown must match the adjacent tile. Special fields provide surprise effects. And the classics such as "two draw" or "skip" are also present here. For the penultimate card, announce "mau"; for the last card, "mau mau" also applies. However: "mau mau" is not the end. But only when all fields on the map are occupied. This creates tension: the winner is not who got rid of his cards first, but who has collected the most points.

So it is important to proceed strategically and reach the special fields, because they certainly lead to the coveted point chips. In addition, you usually have several investment options.

—description form the publisher (translated)

The Phantom: Treasures of Drakon is a character driven race through a temple to hoard treasure to save them from the sinking island.

You will encounter hidden traps, sacred rooms and of course your nemesis.

Players use available action points to plan their way through the temple. Your hand of cards can aid your plans to steal items from other players, move faster or down hidden routes, avoid traps.

Each player has a custom dice, player board, unique player power and mini to move around the board.

The competitive game is won by accumulating the most Victory Points, and the game ends at a pre-determined amount of rounds organised at the start. The rounds are arranged in the form of a comic strip. There are also co-operative and solo game modes.

This is a roll-and-move board game, which merges the gameplay of Monopoly with Casino "mini-games."

On a player's turn, they roll two dice and move clock-wise around a board, and take the action of the spot they land on.

If a player lands on a property, and it is unowned, they may purchase it. If it is owned, then they must play the owner rent money.

If they land on "Tough Luck" and "Jackpot" card spots, the player takes a card from the corresponding card pile and follows the instructions on the chosen card.

The unique aspect of the game is that if you land on a "Casino" spot, then the player plays a Casino "mini-game." There are four mini-games: Roulette, Black Jack, Craps, and slots. (The game comes with a small roulette wheel, and dice to replicate slot machines.) Players can place bets on these games.

The first player to reach $35,000 (or the person with the most money after a set amount of time) is the winner.

—user summary

The deadliest martial arts experts have gathered in a secret arena to engage the ultimate stealth assassin showdown. As each is evenly matched in strength, skill, and speed, only cunning and courage will tell who will be the last one standing.

Ninjas!! The Stealth Assassin Showdown is a battle royale board game for 2 to 4 players, who use deduction to find and strike moving opponents while trying to evade attacks themselves.

The game is played on a 10-by-10 grid, and involves playable Move and Attack cards, as well as Ninja Star and Footprint tokens. Each player begins with the same hand of 12 cards--the 12 Styles of Ninja, which depict and describe the strategies in the ninja's toolbox, and which can be used to help find, hit, or dodge opponents. Turns alternate between Moves and Attacks, in which all players plan secretly, and then reveal and resolve simultaneously. Players record their own turns and track evidence of their opponents' movements in writing on a Notepad.

Although the in-game goals remain the same for every game of Ninjas!!, players can change the end-game conditions to allow for different game times and styles of gameplay. The standard game involved 3 wounds and player elimination, other options include Sudden Death matches as well as point-based games in which players count the number of successful attacks against the number of times they were wounded. Each game of Ninjas!! can also be played on a differently laid out board and with different starting positions.

-description from publisher

Set in a post apocalyptic world destroyed by climate change, Tremor is a 2 to 4 player medium weight strategy game where you redesign and rearrange the board every turn.  As an animal ancestral spirit,  to win you must exploit a disaster-ridden world to help your species progress, while hindering your opponents. The goal is to save your species by helping them reach their last remaining natural habitat in the opposite corner of the board, before your rivals get to theirs.
â€‹
Tremor is played on a modular tile board. On your turn you must take 3 actions in any order: Traverse, Tectonic Twist, and Scout (a choice of component actions Explore and Forecast).

These actions allow players to move across the board towards their goal, reorient tiles, and accumulate Tremor Tokens. Tremor Tokens are placed on the separate Catastrophe Board, and players must strategically allocate and optimise them to ignite a disaster.

There are 6 disasters that will help or hinder your passage to safety. Each of them have unique effects, and the area of the board they affect is based on how you manipulate their position and orientation. You can also evade, combo and amplify their effects by using secret Catastrophe Cards, Disaster Die rolls, and abilities unique to your species.

Tremor can be played as a competitive or team co-operative game. It's easy to learn and hard to master, making it suitable for all skill levels. Games last between 30-60 minutes depending on how seriously you take your strategy.

— Jonah, Curly Bros Games

Onslaught is a fantasy, military unit card game for 2-6 players. Your hand makes up your army and it's you vs everyone else. Using your dice rolls and card special abilities to knock out opponent cards, while withering their retaliation. Can you survive the Onslaught? The last player with any remaining cards gains a victory. Play goes till one champion emerges with two victories.

Players choose between 2 styles of play every time there's a new hand. Either Offense or Defense. Each gives a player unique mode of play with variable powers. This mixed with the card special abilities grants a wide range of tactical options. Players can play to their cards, the benefits of a play style or to their personal preferences. Each hand comes with many diverse possibilities.

Ready to join the battleground? Many may enter, but only one survives the Onslaught!

—description from the publisher

Theme

A Strategic fantasy medieval cards game for 2-8 players, all against all or cooperative.

"Throne is a game of duels, betrayals and false alliances to contend the Throne for world domination. Ancient Guilds will face each other in epic fights without exclusion of sword blow, they will have to defend themselves from the attacks of threatening Dragons and will be able to find comfort with great drinks of good Wine! Will you have the necessary valor to reach the Legendary Kalesh and face its Guardians? What will your destiny reserve? This will depend only on you!"

Game Play

Starting from the youngest player and in order of age, each player chooses their own Guild.
Once the two decks "Main Deck" and "Armory Deck" have been mixed and positioned, the players choose the configuration of the Armory Board, between the two available (the dashboard is double-face). Assign the "Destiny Deck" ordered from 1 to 20 to the first player (the youngest player, or the last winner). Each player selects the Lord (Loyal) or Guardian (Traitor) of the chosen Guild and a random character from the remaining cards of the same Guild. Each players turn consist of 3 main phases, "Draw", "Play", "End of Turn".The round goes clockwise.

     In the "Draw" phase, the player must draws 2 cards from the Main Deck.
     In the "Play" phase the player has no card limits that he can play except for the Constraints (only 1 "Hit Type" card each turn, use the "Valor" ability once, can have a maximum of 4 "Equipments") in play, he can only have one weapon in play, he can use his ability and effects only once each turn),


he can draw buy and sell Armory cards.

     In the third phase "End of Turn", if the player has more than 5 cards in his hand, he discards the excess, if he has less than 5 he can decide to discard all and draw 5 new cards.


The player suffers the effects of the Poison Markers if he owns and finally fight the dragons if they are active in the game.

Goals of the Game
 The players will play with the aim of conquering the enemy Guild tokens, which are won by eliminating the characters owned by each opponents with their own cards.

—description from the publisher (translated)

Throne - I Guardiani di Kalesh è il secondo gioco di Wegas-Studios di Fabio Napolitano. 
Gioco completamente Made in Italy, rilasciato nell'Aprile del 2019.

Tema

Gioco di carte strategico fantasy medievale da 2-8 giocatori, in modalità tutti contro tutti o cooperativa. 
Throne è un gioco di duelli, tradimenti e false alleanze per contendersi l’unico Trono per il dominio del mondo. Antiche Gilde si affronteranno in epici scontri senza esclusione di Colpi, dovranno difendersi dagli attacchi di minacciosi Draghi e potranno trovare conforto con grandi bevute di buon Vino! Avrai il coraggio necessario per raggiungere la Leggendaria Kalesh e fronteggiare i suoi Guardiani? Cosa riserverà il tuo Destino? Questo dipenderà solo da te!

Game Play

A partire dal giocatore più giovane ed in ordine di età, ogni giocatore sceglie la propria Gilda di appartenenza. 
Una volta mescolati e posizionati i due mazzi "Mazzo di Gioco" e "Mazzo Armeria" i giocatori scelgono la configurazione della plancia, tra le due disponibili (la plancia è duble-fas) si assegna il "Mazzo Destino" ordinato da 1 a 20 al Capoturno (il giocatore più giovane). Ogni giocatore seleziona il Lord (Leale) o il Guardiano (Traditore) della gilda scelta e un personaggio a caso dei restanti appartenenti alla stessa gilda. I giocatori affronteranno a rotazione un turno composto da 3 fasi principali, "Pescare", "Giocare", "Fine Turno". 

     Nella fase "Pescare" il giocatore pesca 2 carte dal Mazzo di Gioco. 
     Nella fase "Giocare" il giocatore non ha limiti di carte che può giocare ad eccezione dei Vincoli (1 sola carta di "Tipo Colpo" a turno, usare 1 volta sola l'abilità "Coraggio", può avere massimo 4 "Equipaggiamenti" in gioco, può avere solo un arma in gioco, può usare abilità ed effetti una sola volta a turno), può usare l'abilità del suo personaggio, pescare vendere e acquistare carte dell'Armeria.
     Nella terza fase "Fine Turno" se un giocatore ha più di 5 carte in mano scarta quelle in eccesso, se ne ha meno di 5 può decidere di scartarle tutte e pescarne 5 nuove. 


Il giocatore subisce gli effetti dei Segnalini Veleno se li possiede e in fine affronta i draghi se sono attivi in gioco.

Scopo del Gioco
 I giocatori a turno giocheranno con l'obbiettivo di conquistare i segnalini delle Gilde nemiche, che si conquistano eliminando con le proprie carte i personaggi posseduti dagli avversari.

—description from the publisher (translated)

The Portuguese King has called the finest stonemasons of the country to pave one of the most important squares with calçada tiles (worldwide famous black and white tiles that pave several squares in Portugal). But the task is enormous and players will have to count with the aid of helper cards who will help them score points and/or collect money.

In Rossio, players start the game by drawing five cards and keeping three of them on their hands.

On a player's turn, players will first recruit a card from their hands, placing it on the rightmost space under their player board, sliding to the left all cards previously recruited, discarding the card that slides off their boards (under each player board there are only 3 card slots). If the newly recruited card is played face-up, players must pay its cost in coins. If the card is played face-down, no money needs to be spent.

Then, ALL cards under a player board will activate: face-up cards will give the player Points for each time the pattern depicted on the card is found on the square. Face-down cards will provide the player 1 coin each.

Then, players must build the leftmost calçada tile of their player boards. Players can never voluntarily change the order of the tiles on their board. At any moment players can, however, spend 1 coin to swap 2 pieces on their board that are orthogonally adjacent. The tile must be built in the square orthogonally adjacent to at least 2 elements: 1 tile and 1 wall, or 2 tiles. And must be built on the leftmost available space of the line it is being built. If the players manage to build orthogonally adjacent to a similar tile, they can as bonus build the next leftmost tile, and so on, until they decide to stop or until they can't build more. Players collect then 1 coin for each coin depicted on the spaces that were left free on their player boards after tiles were built.

Finally, players end their turn by drawing 1 card into their hand from the 4 cards available on the market. However, the amount of cards players can choose from depends on the number of tiles that they have built. So, if players build only 1 tile, they must take the 1st card. If they build 3 tiles, for example, they can choose between the 1st, 2nd or 3rd cards. Players end their turns by refilling the empty spaces of their player boards with tiles from the facedown stacks.

As the square is being cooperatively built, certain patterns appear more often than others and the scoring of face-up cards becomes exponential. Also, when players complete a column, they collect a bonus, that can be either 1 coin or drawing more cards. Money is very tight in this game, so gaining an extra coin can be crucial to recruiting a card from your hand face-up.

The game ends when the square is finished and the player with most points wins the game.

Rossio is all about timing: Recruit a card face-up late in the game, and then it will score fewer times than expected. Recruit it too early, and it will score you a few points since there are few tiles built on the square. To many cards recruited face down will give that extra amount of money, but, they won't score any points. Build several tiles and you're probably helping your opponents. Build fewer tiles and you probably won't have money next turn to recruit a face-up card.

Rossio is a game with very simple rules, but with high interaction between players and interesting decisions every single turn.

—description from the designer

Super Punch Fighter is a game of arena battle and video-game powers for 1-6 players. Choose a fighter, grab their deck, and start knocking your opponents off the stage. Each knockout earns you a star, and grabbing an achievement card earns you extra stars. The first player to reach nine stars wins!

In more detail, each turn players can use any of the button cards in front of them to gain extra movement, draw more cards, perform extra attacks, and block damage from opponents. Every time you press a button, you put a thumb token on that button card to show it's been used. You can press as many buttons as you like, but you can remove tokens from at most four cards at the end of your turn. Every other card with a thumb token still on it is then discarded, so pick your buttons wisely!

Aside from mashing buttons, you can play cards from your hand by paying the button cost of the card. Fighter cards are powerful and unique to your fighter. You can play multiple fighter cards on your turn as long as you have the buttons to pay for them, and if the last button on a fighter card matches the first button on the next card you play, you need to put a thumb token on that button only once! Pick the best cards to string together for a super-powered hit!

Super Punch Fighter includes a 1-2 co-operative mode called "Minion Rush" in which waves of minions try to overwhelm the board. Total your stars at the end to determine your rank, from lowly amateur to grand champion.

Statistical simulation game that allows the replay of professional darts tournaments from the 1970s through the 2000s.

Each historical player is presented with an Average Performance rating which is added to a roll of five 10-sided dice to determine who has the upper hand in the head to head match-up.  Historical players also have a Tournament rating which can increase the number of dice rolled.

The higher total over three sets of rolls wins the leg, with each match being a best of 11 competition.

—user summary

A straight-forward adaptation of the card game Canasta into a word game.  Instead of clustering traditional cards into melds of identical rank, lettered cards are melded into words.

The Alphanasta deck consists of two packs of 54 cards, which combined include: 40 vowels, 48 consonants, 8 doubles (e.g. J/K or  W/X, where you can use it as either letter), 8 pairs (e.g. ER or ED, where both letters are used in the printed order, and 4 triples (ING). Vowels are worth 5 points each, consonants 10, doubles and pairs 20, and triples 50.

Each player is dealt 13 cards each, or 11 in partnership games. In a turn a player: 
1. Draws: either A) the top of the draw pile, or B) the entire discard pile. B) can only be done if the top discard is used to extend an existing word, or meld a new word of 4+ letters using cards from the hand. 
2. May do this as much as they wish: A) meld new words from the hand of 4+ letters; B) add cards to either end of an tabled word of theirs, making it a new word. 
3. Discards a card from the hand, unless they are going out.

Doubles, pairs, and triples are considered Wild cards for the purposes of impure words (it's impure if it ends in a Wild); and of freezing the discard pile (which cannot be drawn unless the top card is used for a new word of 5+ letters rather than 4+).

A player or team may go out if they have at least two Word Canastas (words of 7+ letters), or one Alphanasta (a word of 10+ letters played from the hand).  At this point all players score the sum of the letter values in the words they have on the table, plus these bonuses: 
100 points for going out
300 an impure Word Canasta 
500 a pure Words Canasta
1000 an Alphanasta
100 for each letter over 7 in a Word Canasta.

The first player to reach 3000 points over several hands, or 5000 for partnership games, wins.

—user summary

The deck has 100 cards, each with a letter and its point value. (The letters have either a goldenrod or a turquoise background, but this has no game value.)

Each player is dealt 7 cards, and 7 more area dealt to the initial discard pile. In turn each player may discard any number of their cards and then draw that many from the deck or discard pile (but not both). This is done a second time, and then players have 60 second to form their hand into words.  Players then get the point value of all the cards in the longest word they make, with a bonus of 10 points going to the best hand (typically the hand with the longest word).  Hands are done until an agreed time is expired or an agreed winning point total is reached.

—user summary

Includes 200 letter cards and a sand timer.

Each player draws 16 letters face down. The timer is turned, and each player turns their letters face up, arranges them into a 4x4 grid, and moves them around to form the longest word they can find. When time runs out, if the word is valid, they keep the letters used, and the rest are returned.

After 4 rounds, the player with the most kept letters wins. Play can be varied in difficulty with more or fewer letters, or in length with more or fewer rounds.

—user summary

Wordage has two identical decks; one deck is used for 2-4 players, both decks for 5-8 players. Each deck has: 3 A's and E's, 2 O's, I's and S's, and 1 of each other letter, all in red, and the same again all in black, plus two Joiner cards that can stand for any letter, making 68 cards. Each letter has a point value of 1-5.

Each player is dealt 14 cards (children 10 cards), and during their turn a player draws a card, lays down cards if possible, and discards a card. The initial lay-down must be one or more words that have at least 14 points in value and include at least one 5+ letter word in one color (for children, at least 10 points and no color requirement). A word's value is the sum of its letters' values, plus bonuses for length, doubled if the word is of one color.

In turns after the initial lay-down, a player may also: draw the top discard instead of the top of the deck; add letters to any word on the table instead of playing a new word (this doesn't score points, though); replace a Joiner (wild) card with the letter it currently stands from from the hand.

The player who plays all the cards in their hand except one which is then discarded, wins the round. The game is won by the first player to win two rounds consecutively; for shorter games, the consecutive requirement is dropped.

In the party version of the game, points for words played are tallied and totaled -- a score pad is included -- and a round's winner gets a bonus of 50 points plus the values of the cards left in others' hands.

—user summary

Whoever thought that telling someone to “Go to Hell!” would be a compliment? Gather your friends and family together for a devilish dash through the fiery pits of Dante’s Inferno! Compete with your loved ones to be the first to make your way through all seven deadly sins and go to Hell. It includes one gameboard, one die, four game pieces and 20 Hell Cards! Just don't get sent to Heaven unless you have the Get Out of Heaven Free card. It's a race to the bottom that's so much fun, it's sinful!

—description from the publisher

The game contains 64 cards with pictures and the corresponding words and 32 envolopes.

The kids put all cards in the envelopes so that they can only read the words. The envelopes are put face down on the table and the start player takes one envelope and tries to read the word. If he doesn't manage to, he opens the envelope and looks at the picture and let everybody else know what he sees.

Then the player can have a look at another envelope to find pairs.

—user summary

Loriots Spielekiste ("Loriots game box") contains two games from Loriot:

     Way to success
     Rummy with Loriot images

In FlipFlick, players will take on the role of a pancake chef as they prepare different beautiful pancake variations and yummy all-time favourites.

While cooking, the chefs will take actions and collect points for the pancakes they successfully flip. Players will make a choice of how much risk they are going to take in flipping the pancakes by flicking one, two or three pancake cards with their fingers and catching them again. Different markers on the cards indicate different levels of risk. The higher the risk, the more difficult the flip, the more points to win – and to lose, of course.

As competing chefs, players will have to interfere with their fellow co-chefs’ pancake flips and also steal their nicest creations to their advantage.

The player with the right combination of pancakes and the highest points wins.

-description from artist

In this in-hand, cards-only solo deck management game, you are a runner who went for a morning jog in the wrong labyrinth. Now, three doors and a rampaging Minotaur stand between you and the escape tunnel at the center of the maze.

Your goal as the player is to find and discard all three door cards from the deck before you discard three Minotaur cards.

Each turn, you'll choose to uncover either the left or right side of the next card in the deck, and the side you reveal will have a symbol that tells you whether you'll need to turn the card you moved before placing it back in the deck. Then choose one of two possible locations to place the card back in the deck, and repeat with the next card until you either escape...or fall to the Minotaur.

With convenient in-hand play, simple but deep deck management, dynamically scaling difficulty, three game modes to try, and easy pausing, this is a deathtrap you'll never want to leave home without!

This game was developed as an entry in the 2019 9 Card Game Print and Play Design Contest, where it won several awards, including:

     #2 Best Cards-Only Game
     #3 Most Innovative Mechanism
     #7 Best Solitaire Game


—description from the designer

Based on the best selling MAD DOGS Indian Mutiny rules. Medium to large scale battles. Inc sample army lists and scenarios. Inc Jacobite Wars and War in the East.

—description from publisher

A standalone expansion for När då då (The Best of Chronology) with cards containing trivia about famous buildings.

Gameplay is similar to the original game. On the players turn, an opponent draws a card from the deck and reads the text on the card. If the player successfully points out where the card should go in their current timeline, the card is added above the player Time lock and the player may then either decide to end the turn and move the cards above the time lock to the safety below it or try to get another card. If the player fails to place a card correctly, all cards gained in the current turn are lost, the turn ends and play passes to the next player.

The winner is the first player to win five cards.

When used with the original game, the cards from this game is added as another category. A new six-sided die and cardboard markers 1-6 are included to choose the category.

—user summary

GAME GOALS
Idea of game is to, through shrewd purchasing and luck, manage to survive by either bonging your self or your friends to oblivion.
RULES
BASIC EQUIPMENT The game consist of the BOARD, with space over which the player's pieces are moved. There are two DICE, TOKEN of various color , TWO sets of card for CHANCE and BOOBY-TRAP pace . There i a TITLE DEED card for every property and FOUR canister which hold the Bonging material or STASH of your choice and with this material you purchase the properties.
STARTING THE GAME Place board on table with Chance and Booby-Trap cards face down on their allotted paces. Each player is provided one colored token to represent him on his travels around the board. The bonging material or stash is used to purchase, pay penalties or rent for properties on the board. NOTE: Each player must supply their own stash and all players must begin with EQUAL amounts of STASH. Recommended for this game is at least one canister of cleaned bonging material or stash for each player. NOTE: ONE player must also supply a Bong to be used in conjunction with this game.That player is elected BONGMASTER( See Bongmaster).Each player chooses one colored token and shakes one dice. The player with the highest total start the game first. All players place their TOKE on the corner marked UNEMPLOYMENT COMPENSATION "GO".
Upon landing on the space with his TOKEN, a player may be entitled to purchase RealEstate or other properties -or be obliged to pay bongs, pay taxes, draw a Chance or Booby-Trap card or "You Have Been Busted", etc.
If a player passes out or is unable to continue to play PRIOR to going bankrupt, all of that player's assets are divided as equally as possible by the players on each side of him.
The game is won by the last player not to go bankrupt (or pass out).
